Coloured Progressive Matrices (CPM): Easier version for children ages 5-11 and individuals with cognitive impairment. Uses colored backgrounds to maintain attention.
Advanced Progressive Matrices (APM): More difficult version for above-average adults and adolescents.
Strengths: Minimal verbal demands; can be administered to non-English speakers; strong measure of Gf and g; widely researched cross-culturally; brief administration

Limitations: Measures only one narrow facet of intelligence (nonverbal reasoning); no verbal, memory, or processing speed components; not a substitute for comprehensive cognitive assessment; still shows cultural effects despite being "nonverbal"
The examiner says a word and the examinee selects the picture (from four options) that best represents that word
Yields a standard score (M = 100, SD = 15), percentile rank, stanine, and age equivalent
Screening for verbal ability, particularly when the examinee cannot produce oral responses (e.g., autism, selective mutism, severe speech impairment)
Often paired with the Expressive Vocabulary Test (EVT-3) to compare receptive and expressive language abilities
Not a measure of overall intelligence -- it assesses only receptive vocabulary (a narrow aspect of crystallized ability)
Cognitive Battery subtests: Figure Ground, Form Completion, Classification/Analogies, Sequential Order -- yield a nonverbal IQ (M = 100, SD = 15)
Attention/Memory Battery: Attention Sustained, Forward Memory, Reverse Memory, Nonverbal Stroop -- yield attention and memory composites
Profile pattern (e.g., V+ indicates verbal strength; N- indicates nonverbal weakness)
Using abstract geometric or figural content rather than content tied to specific cultural knowledge
Select instruments normed on populations that include the examinee's demographic group
Consider whether nonverbal instructions (as in the Leiter-3) are necessary, or whether nonverbal test content with verbal instructions (as in Raven's) is sufficient
Use multiple measures rather than a single nonverbal test to get a more comprehensive picture
Report results with appropriate caveats about the limitations of nonverbal assessment
Recognize that nonverbal IQ scores may underrepresent the abilities of verbally strong individuals
Avoid using a single nonverbal screening measure as a definitive measure of intellectual functioning
The KABC-II can be interpreted using either of two frameworks:
The CogAT uses a unique ability profile system that describes the pattern of scores across the three batteries:

Best available research evidence -- includes meta-analyses, RCTs, effectiveness studies, single-case designs, qualitative research, and clinical observation. The hierarchy typically places systematic reviews and RCTs at the top, but all levels of evidence contribute.

Clinical expertise -- refers to the competencies acquired through education, training, and experience, including assessment skill, diagnostic acumen, case formulation, treatment planning, therapeutic relationship management, and self-reflection.

Patient characteristics, culture, and preferences -- encompasses the client's values, goals, religious beliefs, worldview, cultural identity, socioeconomic context, readiness for change, social support, and treatment preferences.
Perpetuating factors (e.g., avoidance patterns, cognitive distortions, environmental reinforcement)
Problem complexity / chronicity: More complex or chronic problems may require longer-term, insight-oriented approaches
Coping style: Internalizers (high self-blame) respond better to insight-oriented treatments; externalizers respond better to symptom-focused, skill-building approaches
Resistance level / reactance: Highly resistant clients respond better to nondirective approaches; low-resistance clients respond well to directive approaches
Subjective distress: Moderate distress levels optimize treatment engagement; very low or very high distress may impede progress
Agreement on goals: Therapist and client share an understanding of the targets of treatment
Agreement on tasks: Both parties agree on the activities and methods used in therapy
The relational bond: Mutual trust, respect, liking, and attachment between therapist and client
Empathy: The therapist's ability to understand the client's experience (r = .28 with outcome)
Extratherapeutic factors: Client variables and life events outside of therapy -- Lambert (1992) estimated these account for approximately 40% of outcome variance
Outcome Questionnaire-45 (OQ-45): Lambert's 45-item self-report measure assessing symptom distress, interpersonal relations, and social role functioning. Most extensively researched feedback tool.
Session Rating Scale (SRS) and Outcome Rating Scale (ORS): Miller and Duncan's ultra-brief (4-item each) measures of the therapeutic alliance and client functioning
Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9): 9-item depression severity measure commonly used in integrated care settings
PCOMS (Partners for Change Outcome Management System): An integrated feedback system using the ORS and SRS
Approximately 50% of clients show clinically significant improvement by session 8
There are diminishing returns with additional sessions, though some clients require longer treatment
The rate of improvement is fastest in the earliest sessions (negatively accelerating curve)

passages.section: The Dodo Bird Verdict and Its Critics
passages.passage: Supporting evidence: Meta-analyses by Wampold (2001) found minimal differences between active treatments when researcher allegiance and other confounds are controlled

passages.section: The Dodo Bird Verdict and Its Critics
passages.passage: Opposing evidence: For specific disorders, some treatments show clear superiority (e.g., ERP for OCD, exposure therapy for specific phobias, behavioral treatments for autism spectrum disorder)

passages.section: The Dodo Bird Verdict and Its Critics
passages.passage: Middle ground: Most researchers now accept that common factors are powerful, but specific techniques add incremental value for certain conditions

Cultural adaptation of ESTs: Research supports that culturally adapted treatments (those modified to account for the client's language, cultural values, and worldview) are more effective for ethnic minority clients than unadapted versions (Griner & Smith, 2006, d = 0.45)
Therapist cultural competence: The therapist's ability to understand and work within the client's cultural framework enhances the therapeutic alliance and improves outcomes

Client treatment preferences: Racial and ethnic minority clients may have preferences for certain treatment approaches or may be less likely to engage with treatments perceived as culturally incongruent
Access and retention: Structural barriers (language, transportation, insurance, stigma) disproportionately affect minority populations and must be considered in treatment planning
Motivational enhancement: For clients low in motivation, beginning with motivational interviewing (MI) before introducing structured treatments improves engagement and outcomes
Stepped care: Starting with less intensive interventions and stepping up to more intensive treatments as needed is both cost-effective and clinically sound

Alliance rupture repair: Safran and Muran (2000) demonstrated that identifying and repairing alliance ruptures (confrontation ruptures and withdrawal ruptures) is associated with improved outcomes, particularly with difficult-to-engage clients

Therapist effects: Some therapists consistently achieve better outcomes than others. Therapist effects account for approximately 5-8% of outcome variance, comparable to or exceeding the contribution of specific techniques
The Transtheoretical Model suggests that interventions should match the client's readiness for change:
Bordin's (1979) pantheoretical model defines the alliance as consisting of three components:
Lambert (1992) proposed the following estimated contributions to therapeutic outcome:
EBPP requires that treatment selection account for patient cultural context. Key considerations include:
Congruence: People are most satisfied and productive when their personality type matches their work environment (e.g., an Artistic person in an Artistic job)

Consistency: Some type combinations are more related to each other (adjacent on the hexagon, e.g., RI or SE) than others (opposite, e.g., RA or SC). Consistent profiles are more stable and predictable.

Differentiation: A person who strongly resembles one type and little resembles others is well-differentiated. A flat profile (similar scores across all types) is undifferentiated and harder to interpret.
Calculus: The hexagonal arrangement reflects the relationships among the types -- adjacent types are most similar; opposite types are most different
The GOT profile provides the Holland code (e.g., ISA, SEC) used to identify congruent occupations
A high score on an occupational scale indicates that the examinee's pattern of interests is similar to that of satisfied workers in that occupation
The SDS consists of four sections: Activities (liked/disliked), Competencies (can/cannot do), Occupations (appealing/not), and Self-Estimates (self-rated abilities)
The three highest scores form the individual's three-letter Holland code (called the Summary Code)
The code is then used with the Occupations Finder or Dictionary of Holland Occupational Codes to identify matching occupations
Strengths: Self-administered and quick (20-30 minutes); cost-effective for group use; strong theoretical foundation; well-validated
Limitations: Less detailed than the Strong; self-scoring can lead to errors; relies heavily on self-estimates that may be biased; less useful for individuals with undifferentiated profiles
Each item presents three activities, and the examinee selects the most preferred and least preferred
This forced-choice format reduces the tendency toward acquiescence (saying "like" to everything) or social desirability
Scores are ipsative (within-person comparisons) rather than normative (compared to a reference group)
Concurrent validity: Individuals in a given occupation tend to score highest on the corresponding scale
Predictive validity: Interest scores measured in adolescence or young adulthood predict occupational choice years later at moderate levels (r ~ .30-.40)
Hit rates: The Strong correctly predicts occupational group membership in approximately 50% of cases over long follow-up periods

Interests + abilities: High interest without corresponding aptitude may lead to frustration; high aptitude without interest may lead to dissatisfaction. Comprehensive career assessment evaluates both.

Interests + values: Work values (e.g., autonomy, financial security, altruism) add a dimension beyond what interest inventories measure. Instruments like the Work Values Inventory can supplement interest results.
Interests + personality: Personality measures (e.g., NEO-PI-R, MBTI) can help explain why certain interests exist and how they might manifest in different work environments.
Interests + developmental context: Consider the client's age, life stage, career development stage (Super's Life-Span model), and prior work experiences when interpreting interest profiles.
The SII also includes five Personal Style Scales that assess preferences in work style:

Original MMPI (1943): Hathaway and McKinley developed the instrument at the University of Minnesota using empirical criterion keying -- items were selected based on their ability to discriminate between clinical groups and normals, not based on item content

MMPI-2 (1989): Butcher, Dahlstrom, Graham, Tellegen, and Kaemmer restandardized the instrument with a more representative normative sample (N = 2,600). Item content was updated but the clinical scales were preserved. Uniform T-scores were introduced.

MMPI-2-RF (2008): Ben-Porath and Tellegen restructured the instrument using factor analysis, creating 51 scales organized hierarchically. The 10 clinical scales were replaced by Restructured Clinical (RC) scales.
MMPI-3 (2020): Ben-Porath and Tellegen further revised the RF, with updated norms, revised items, and modernized content. 335 items, 52 scales.
Clinical scales use Uniform T-scores (developed by Auke Tellegen) to ensure comparable percentile rankings across scales
Scales 5 (Mf) and 0 (Si) use linear T-scores rather than uniform T-scores because their distributions are close to normal
Higher-Order (H-O) Scales (3): Emotional/Internalizing Dysfunction (EID), Thought Dysfunction (THD), Behavioral/Externalizing Dysfunction (BXD)

Restructured Clinical (RC) Scales (9): The core interpretive scales RCd: Demoralization (general unhappiness/distress) RC1: Somatic Complaints RC2: Low Positive Emotions RC3: Cynicism RC4: Antisocial Behavior RC6: Ideas of Persecution RC7: Dysfunctional Negative Emotions RC8: Aberrant Experiences RC9: Hypomanic Activation
Specific Problems (SP) Scales (23): Provide detailed information within domains (e.g., Head Pain Complaints, Stress/Worry, Juvenile Conduct Problems)
Interest Scales (2): Aesthetic-Literary Interests, Mechanical-Physical Interests

Personality Psychopathology Five (PSY-5) Scales (5): Aggressiveness-Revised, Psychoticism-Revised, Disconstraint-Revised, Negative Emotionality/Neuroticism-Revised, Introversion/Low Positive Emotionality-Revised
Updated normative sample (N = 1,620) that is more representative of the U.S. population
The MMPI-3 replaces some specific problems scales and adds new ones (e.g., Compulsivity, Self-Importance)
Age: 18+ for all MMPI instruments (the MMPI-A and MMPI-A-RF are the adolescent versions for ages 14-18)
Reading level: Approximately sixth grade for the MMPI-2; similar for MMPI-2-RF and MMPI-3
Format: True/False items; can be administered via booklet, computer, or audio recording
Completion of first 370 items of the MMPI-2 allows scoring of all validity and clinical scales (the remaining items contribute to supplementary and content scales)
The MMPI-2-RF and MMPI-3 use non-gendered norms (combined male/female reference group)

K-correction is applied to five clinical scales on the MMPI-2 (Scales 1, 4, 7, 8, 9) -- a proportion of the K score is added to compensate for defensiveness. K-correction is NOT used on the MMPI-2-RF or MMPI-3.
Evaluate validity scales: Determine whether the profile is valid and interpretable. Check CNS, VRIN, TRIN, F, L, K, Fb, Fp, S
Examine overall profile elevation: Look at how many scales are elevated above 65T
Identify code type: Determine the two or three highest clinical scales and look up the corresponding code type interpretation
Examine individual scale elevations: Consider the meaning of each elevated scale
Review Harris-Lingoes subscales: Clarify what content is driving clinical scale elevations
Examine content and supplementary scales: Use additional scales (e.g., Anxiety, Depression, Addiction Acknowledgment) to refine interpretation
Integrate with clinical data: Combine MMPI results with interview, history, behavioral observation, and other test data
NEO-PI-R: 240 items on a 5-point Likert scale; 5 domain scores and 30 facet scores
Includes three validity indices: Acquiescence, Nay-Saying, and Random Responding
185 items measuring 16 primary factor scales and 5 global (second-order) factors

The 16 primary factors include: Warmth, Reasoning, Emotional Stability, Dominance, Liveliness, Rule-Consciousness, Social Boldness, Sensitivity, Vigilance, Abstractedness, Privateness, Apprehension, Openness to Change, Self-Reliance, Perfectionism, Tension
The 5 global factors approximate the Big Five: Extraversion, Anxiety, Tough-Mindedness, Independence, Self-Control
Scores are reported as sten scores (standard ten scores, M = 5.5, SD = 2, range 1-10)
Clinical assessment of personality style (not primarily a clinical/pathology instrument)

Three types of scales: Clinical Personality Pattern scales (15): Correspond to DSM personality disorders (e.g., Schizoid, Avoidant, Dependent, Histrionic, Narcissistic, Antisocial, Compulsive, Negativistic, Masochistic, Sadistic, Schizotypal, Borderline, Paranoid) Clinical Syndrome scales (7): Generalized Anxiety, Somatic Symptom, Bipolar Spectrum, Persistent Depression, Alcohol Use, Drug Use, Post-Traumatic Stress Severe Clinical Syndrome scales (3): Schizophrenic Spectrum, Major Depression, Delusional

Clinical Personality Pattern scales (15): Correspond to DSM personality disorders (e.g., Schizoid, Avoidant, Dependent, Histrionic, Narcissistic, Antisocial, Compulsive, Negativistic, Masochistic, Sadistic, Schizotypal, Borderline, Paranoid)
Clinical Syndrome scales (7): Generalized Anxiety, Somatic Symptom, Bipolar Spectrum, Persistent Depression, Alcohol Use, Drug Use, Post-Traumatic Stress
Severe Clinical Syndrome scales (3): Schizophrenic Spectrum, Major Depression, Delusional
Validity indices: Invalidity, Inconsistency, Disclosure, Desirability, Debasement
BR scores are anchored to the prevalence (base rate) of each disorder in clinical populations
BR score of 75 = presence of the trait/syndrome; BR score of 85 = prominence (clinically significant)
This approach accounts for the fact that different disorders have different base rates in clinical settings
Normed only on clinical (psychiatric) populations -- should not be used with non-clinical samples
Tied specifically to Millon's theory; may not map perfectly onto all DSM conceptualizations
Scales overlap substantially (items shared across scales), which inflates inter-scale correlations
Administration: Two phases -- Response Phase (free association to each card) and Inquiry Phase (examiner clarifies what and where the examinee saw each percept)

Scoring categories: Location (W = whole, D = common detail, Dd = unusual detail), Determinants (form, color, shading, movement), Content (human, animal, anatomy, etc.), Popular responses, Organizational Activity (Z-scores)
Structural Summary: A quantitative compilation of all coded scores, including ratios, percentages, and derived indices
Erlebnistypus (EB): Ratio of human movement (M) to weighted color responses (WSumC) -- reflects whether the individual is introverted (M > WSumC), extraverted (WSumC > M), or ambitent
Lambda (L): Ratio of pure form responses to all other responses -- high Lambda suggests avoidant, simplistic approach to complexity
X-% and X+%: Measures of perceptual accuracy (reality testing). X+% = conventional form quality; X-% = distorted form quality. Elevated X-% suggests impaired reality testing.
SCZI / PTI (Perceptual-Thinking Index): Identifies thought disorder and perceptual distortion associated with psychotic processes
DEPI (Depression Index): Identifies features associated with affective disturbance
S-CON (Suicide Constellation): Risk index for suicidal behavior (one of the best-validated indices)
Standardized response process: Prompts examinees to give 2-3 responses per card (reduces variability in number of responses)
Evidence-based variable selection (retained variables with the strongest empirical support; dropped poorly validated ones)
Needs: Internal drives and motives of the protagonist (who is assumed to represent the examinee)
Press: Environmental forces acting on the protagonist (reflecting the examinee's perceived environment)
Thema: The interaction between needs and press -- the story's central conflict and resolution
The TAT lacks a universally accepted scoring system, which is a major psychometric limitation
Notable systems include: Murray's need-press analysis, Bellak's system, McClelland's need for achievement (nAch) scoring, Westen's SCORS (Social Cognition and Object Relations Scale)

SCORS (Westen): The best-validated TAT scoring system; assesses complexity of representations of people, affective quality of relationships, emotional investment in relationships, and understanding of social causality
Rotter Incomplete Sentences Blank (RISB): 40 stems scored on a 7-point scale from positive adjustment (0-1) to maladjustment (4-6). Yields a total adjustment score. Has adequate psychometric support.

Washington University Sentence Completion Test (WUSCT): Developed by Loevinger to measure ego development. Responses are scored for developmental stage (Impulsive, Self-Protective, Conformist, Conscientious, Autonomous, Integrated).
Developed by Karen Machover (1949) based on the assumption that drawings reflect self-concept and body image
Features such as size, detail, placement, and erasures are interpreted qualitatively
The DAP:SPED (Draw-A-Person: Screening Procedure for Emotional Disturbance) is a standardized scoring system with better psychometric properties than clinical interpretation
The examinee draws a house, a tree, and a person; each drawing is then discussed in a post-drawing inquiry
The house is said to represent family/home life, the tree represents growth and development, and the person represents self-concept
Used primarily with children to assess family dynamics, roles, and relationships
The TAT is based on Murray's need-press theory. Responses are interpreted in terms of:
Approximately 68% of scores fall within +/- 1 standard deviation (SD) of the mean
The z-score distribution has the same shape as the original raw score distribution (it is a linear transformation that does not normalize the distribution)
MMPI-2, MMPI-2-RF, MMPI-3: All scales reported as T-scores (clinical significance at T >= 65)
Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF): T-scores with clinical cutoff at 65
Linear T-scores: Direct transformation of raw scores (preserves original distribution shape). Used on MMPI-2 Scales 5 and 0.
Normalized T-scores: Raw scores are first transformed to percentile ranks, then converted to T-scores based on the normal distribution. This forces the distribution into a normal shape.

Uniform T-scores: Used on most MMPI-2 clinical scales. A method developed by Tellegen that ensures the percentile value of a given T-score is the same across all scales, even though the raw score distributions differ.
Percentile ranks are ordinal, not interval -- equal differences in percentiles do NOT represent equal differences in ability
Percentile ranks are compressed near the mean (where most scores cluster) and stretched at the extremes
Unlike percentile ranks, NCEs are on an equal-interval scale and can be meaningfully averaged
The SEM is assumed to be constant across all score levels (though in practice, it may vary)
Used in neuropsychological re-evaluation to determine whether cognitive decline is beyond what measurement error would predict
Provides an objective criterion for "reliable" change rather than relying on arbitrary cutoffs

A student who scores very high on a test is likely to score somewhat lower on retest (and vice versa) -- not because their ability changed, but because the extreme score was partly due to random error in the favorable direction
Regression to the mean is more pronounced when reliability is lower (more error variance) and when the initial score is more extreme
This effect must be considered when evaluating treatment outcomes: improvement from an extremely low baseline may partly reflect regression to the mean rather than true treatment effects

The estimated true score = M + rxx(X - M), where M = population mean, rxx = reliability, and X = observed score. This formula shows that the estimated true score is always closer to the mean than the observed score (regressed toward the mean by a factor of the reliability coefficient)
Age equivalent: The age at which the individual's raw score is the average performance. A 7-year-old with an age equivalent of 9:6 performs like the average 9-year-6-month-old.
Grade equivalent: The grade level at which the individual's raw score is the average. A 4th grader with a grade equivalent of 6.2 performs like the average student in the 2nd month of 6th grade.
Both are ordinal scales and are widely criticized because they are often misinterpreted (e.g., a 2nd grader with a grade equivalent of 5.0 in math does not necessarily know 5th-grade math content)
Age and grade equivalents should not be used for comparison across different tests or subtests
Similarities: How are two words alike? Measures verbal abstract reasoning and concept formation
Vocabulary: Define words. Measures word knowledge, verbal expression, and crystallized ability
Information: General knowledge questions. Measures breadth of acquired knowledge and long-term memory
Comprehension (supplemental): Social judgment questions. Measures practical reasoning and social knowledge

Block Design: Replicate patterns using red-and-white blocks within time limits. Measures visual-spatial analysis, construction, and nonverbal problem-solving. Often considered the best single nonverbal measure of g.
Matrix Reasoning: Select the missing element from a visual pattern. Measures fluid reasoning with minimal motor demands
Visual Puzzles: Identify pieces that combine to form a target design. Measures visual-spatial reasoning
Figure Weights (supplemental): Quantitative fluid reasoning using visual balance scale
Digit Span: Three conditions -- Forward (attention, short-term memory), Backward (working memory, mental manipulation), and Sequencing (working memory, cognitive flexibility)
Arithmetic: Mental math problems. Measures working memory, attention, and numerical reasoning
Symbol Search: Visual scanning task -- does the target symbol match any in the row? Measures processing speed and visual discrimination
Coding: Transcribe symbol-number pairs using a key. Measures processing speed, visual-motor coordination, and incidental learning
Significant discrepancies between indices (e.g., VCI-PRI or WMI-PSI) may have clinical significance but must be interpreted in context
WMI or PSI scores are significantly lower than VCI/PRI (e.g., in ADHD, TBI, or processing disorders)
The clinician wants to estimate cognitive ability without the confound of processing speed deficits
Core subtests: Receptive Vocabulary, Information, Block Design, Object Assembly, Picture Memory
Subtests use manipulatives, colorful stimuli, and game-like formats to maintain the attention of young children
Test-retest reliability is somewhat lower than for older-child and adult versions (due to developmental variability at young ages)
The SB5 measures each factor in both verbal and nonverbal domains (the Wechsler scales do not systematically do this)
The SB5 uses a routing procedure; the Wechsler scales use age-based starting points
The SB5 has a wider score range (extended IQ from 40 to 160), which is useful at the extremes
The Wechsler scales generally have more subtests and offer more detailed clinical information within each domain
When a new edition of a test is normed, the normative sample performs better than the previous edition's sample, resulting in slightly lower scores on the new edition
Using an outdated test version can inflate IQ scores by approximately 3 points per decade since the norms were established
The Flynn Effect is larger for fluid intelligence measures (~5 points/decade) than for crystallized measures (~2 points/decade)

This has significant forensic implications, particularly in Atkins v. Virginia (2002) intellectual disability death penalty cases, where the version of the test used can affect whether an individual falls above or below the IQ 70 cutoff

Stratum II: Broad abilities -- Gf (Fluid Reasoning), Gc (Crystallized Ability), Gv (Visual Processing), Gsm (Short-Term Memory), Gs (Processing Speed), Glr (Long-Term Retrieval), Ga (Auditory Processing), Gq (Quantitative Knowledge), and others

Fluid Intelligence (Gf): The ability to reason, solve novel problems, and identify patterns without relying on previously acquired knowledge. Largely biologically determined. Peaks in young adulthood and declines with age.

Crystallized Intelligence (Gc): Accumulated knowledge, vocabulary, and skills acquired through education and experience. Largely culturally and educationally influenced. Continues to grow throughout the lifespan (or at least remains stable into late life).
